message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of developmental delay, seizures, protrusion of the mandible, strabismus, and a laughing facial expression suggests Angelman Syndrome, which is caused by loss of function of the maternal ubiquitin protein ligase E3A (UBE3A) gene on chromosome 15. Uniparental disomy of chromosome 15 is one of the genetic mechanisms that can cause Angelman Syndrome. The other options are not associated with the specific combination of findings seen in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, such as developmental delay, seizures, and abnormal facial expression suggest Angelman Syndrome, which is caused by maternal uniparental disomy of chromosome 15. The other options are associated with different syndromes, such as DiGeorge Syndrome, Rett Syndrome, and Fragile X Syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a diagnosis of Angelman syndrome, which is caused by loss of function of the maternally inherited allele on chromosome 15 due to uniparental disomy, deletion, or a mutation. Option A refers to DiGeorge syndrome, option B refers to Rett syndrome, and option D refers to Fragile X syndrome, which are all different genetic disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including developmental delay, seizures, and a small head circumference, suggest uniparental disomy of chromosome 15, which is associated with Angelman syndrome. MECP2 mutations are associated with Rett syndrome, Trinucleotide repeat in FMR1 gene is associated with Fragile X syndrome, and Chromosome 22q11 microdeletion is associated with DiGeorge syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of this patient suggest that he may have Angelman syndrome, which is caused by uniparental disomy of chromosome 15 (inherited from the mother). Chromosome 22q11 microdeletion is associated with DiGeorge syndrome. MECP2 mutation is associated with Rett syndrome. Trinucleotide repeat in FMR1 gene is associated with Fragile X syndrome. None of these conditions fit with the patient's symptoms as well as Angelman syndrome does.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Angelman syndrome, which is a genetic disorder caused by uniparental disomy of chromosome 15. Options A, B, and D are not associated with the specific symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical exam findings suggest Angelman syndrome, which is caused by uniparental disomy of chromosome 15. All other options are associated with different genetic disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The protrusion of the mandible, strabismus, laughing facial expression, and unsteady gait suggest the diagnosis of Angelman syndrome. Angelman syndrome is caused by uniparental disomy of chromosome 15, meaning that both copies of chromosome 15 are inherited from one parent instead of one copy from each parent. This results in inappropriate expression of certain genes on chromosome 15. The other options are not associated with Angelman syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a diagnosis of Angelman syndrome, which is caused by uniparental disomy of chromosome 15. Options A, B, and D are associated with other genetic disorders, such as DiGeorge syndrome, Rett syndrome, and Fragile X syndrome, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Angelman syndrome, which is caused by uniparental disomy of chromosome 15. None of the other options are associated with the characteristic features seen in Angelman syndrome.
